aboutustitle: Join us in this transformative journey towards a greener, more sustainable future.
aboutusline1: Our vision is to invigorate green projects by facilitating their access to international carbon market funding through our robust carbon registry. This platform empowers project developers to harness vital funds that drive environmental innovation, while buyers of carbon credits gain access to a credible, transparent marketplace for their climate action efforts. Ultimately, the registry is a catalyst for our nation's shift towards a sustainable future, enabling us to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, foster a cleaner environment, and promote socio-economic development.
aboutusline2: When you join our National Carbon Registry, you become part of a meaningful movement for change. For project developers, this platform could be your gateway to funding, offering a space to connect with potential buyers of your carbon credits. For buyers, this is your one-stop-shop to find a broad selection of certified credits, contributing towards your carbon neutral goals. By becoming a member, you are joining a community committed to fostering a healthier environment and a sustainable future for our country.
aboutusline3: The National Carbon Registry is our commitment to transparency and integrity in the carbon market. It's a platform designed to facilitate fair and secure transactions of carbon credits. Our aim is to instill confidence in the market and ensure that everyone's contributions towards reducing greenhouse gases are validated and make a real impact. Together, we can effectively combat climate change and pave the way towards a cleaner, more sustainable future for our country. The concept for our National Carbon Registry evolved out of a need for improved carbon credit management. Under the Paris Agreement, an international consensus was reached acknowledging the crucial role of carbon markets in tackling climate change. But, it was evident that an organized, transparent system was required to facilitate these exchanges.
eligibilitybody: The national carbon registry should be adapted to the national context while following below principles.
analyticbody: Our national carbon registry provides full transparency and traceability of carbon credits, ensuring every credit is accurately recorded, independently verified, and uniquely identifiable, giving you complete confidence in your climate action efforts.
carboncalbody: With our easy-to-navigate platform, you can efficiently explore, validate, and engage with a diverse range of verified green projects, simplifying your access to global carbon markets.
serialgenbody: Our carbon registry not only showcases projects that reduce greenhouse gases, but also those that deliver substantial social and economic benefits, allowing you to contribute to a sustainable and resilient future for our nation.
eliglist1: Scope: The Registry should encompass all significant greenhouse gas emissions and removals happening in the country, covering all sectors and gases.
eliglist2: Transparency: The Registry should make the information about emissions and removals publicly available, fostering understanding, trust, and participation among all stakeholders
eliglist3: Consistency: The registry should align with internationally agreed accounting rules, methodologies, and guidelines, particularly the ones provided by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).
eliglist4: Integrity: The registry's data and procedures should be subject to regular review and validation by an independent party to ensure its accuracy and credibility.

heading: NATIONAL CLIMATE TRANSPARENCY PLATFORM
subHeading: Helping Countries Automate and Enhance Climate Reporting
visionDescrption: UNDP has developed the open-source National Climate Transparency Platform (NCTP) to help countries efficiently and securely compile and report information on climate change actions, progress, and support following the Paris Agreement’s Enhanced Transparency Framework (ETF). The NCTP ensures transparency, quality, quick and easy access to national information, while facilitating coordination in data collection across governmental agencies.
visionSupSubtitle1: Provides a quick overview of climate progress and support, allows direct input from data owners, and ensures long-term, accessible information storage—even through staff transitions.
visionSupSubtitle2: Establishes a unified system for government-wide access to climate data, simplifying storage and retrieval, preventing data loss, and ensuring compliance with international reporting requirements.
visionSupSubtitle3: Improves access to support by transparently tracking financial, technical, and capacity-building assistance—helping engage development partners and measure the results of past and ongoing efforts.
whyThisPlatform.title: Why a Digital Transparency Platform?
whyThisPlatform.description:
Article 13 of the Paris Agreement establishes the Enhanced Transparency Framework (ETF) to ensure that all Parties provide clear, consistent, and comparable information on their climate actions and support.
Governments are required to submit Biennial Transparency Reports (BTRs), which include data on greenhouse gas emissions, progress toward nationally determined contributions (NDCs), adaptation efforts, and support provided or received. This reporting enables international review and accountability, helping build trust and track global progress toward climate goals. Due to the volume and complexity of national information required under the ETF, digital systems such as this are essential to help countries consolidate and report information efficiently and effectively.
The open-source National Climate Transparency Platform currently supports longitudinal data collection and automated reporting of common tabular formats for Annex III (Decision 5/CMA.3), with potential to expand to Annex II formats in future releases.

policyContextBody: The Paris Agreement, under the UNFCCC, aims to limit global warming to below 2°C, with efforts to keep it to 1.5°C by 2100. Article 13 establishes the Enhanced Transparency Framework (ETF) action and support that is meant to build mutual trust and confidence and to promote effective implementation of the Paris Agreement. Due to this nature, the ETF covers national information regarding mitigation, adaptation, and cross-cutting climate actions, plus the financial, technology, and capacity-building support needed and received for implementing climate actions.
policyContextBody2: Due to the very large amount of national information in the context of the ETF, digital systems are essential for enabling countries to effectively and efficiently consolidate and report this information over time.
digitalPublicBody: In response to countries’ need for support, UNDP has created the National Climate Transparency Platform as an open-source toolkit that follows the <a1>Digital Public Goods Standard.</a1>. Countries can access the free, open-source code and installation instructions <a2>from UNDP’s managed Github</a2> to customize their own Transparency Platform according to national needs. This approach helps save time, reduce costs, and avoids duplication of effort.

howDoesItWork.Title: How does it work?
howDoesItWork.description: Every country has unique climate policies, planning processes, and information governance structures. The National Climate Transparency Platform (NCTP) is fully customizable to meet these national requirements, while still aligning with the Enhanced Transparency Framework.
features.heading: Key functionalities of the National Climate Transparency Platform
feature.1.title: Assigned users
feature.1.description: Governments can assign access to users based on their organizations (e.g., ministries, academic institutions, consultants) and the specific sectors or data they are responsible for.
feature.2.title: Information structure
feature.2.description: The system follows a modular structure that reflects how countries plan and implement climate actions.  This includes general information on broad climate actions and the more detailed information on sectoral programmes, projects, and activities that fall under each climate action.
feature.3.title: Validation workflows
feature.3.description: Governments can assign validators to review and confirm the accuracy of data entered at the climate action, programme, project, activity, and support levels.
feature.4.title: Standard reporting
feature.4.description: Data entered into the NCTP is automatically consolidated in a dashboard and exported into standard Common Tabular Formats (CTFs) for tables in Annex III and II.
feature.5.title: GHG emissions projections
feature.5.description: A dedicated module enables governments to project greenhouse gas emissions by sector or subsector. Projections can be based on built-in exponential growth models or imported from external modeling software.
faqQ1: Why should governments adopt the NCTP?
faqA1:
The National Climate Transparency Platform (NCTP) helps governments optimize the management of climate-related information across ministries, agencies, and departments. It also enables easy sharing of this information with external stakeholders such as the UNFCCC, development partners, and academic institutions.

By consolidating important data into a single digital platform, improving access, and offering standardized reporting aligned with the Enhanced Transparency Framework (ETF), the NCTP can save thousands of person-hours of work.
faqA2:
To ensure the NCTP is intuitive, it follows a common structure used by governments and development partners to organize national climate actions, sectoral programmes, specific projects and activities, and related financing.

The NCTP allows users to input over 30 types of information required for ETF reporting. It also enables tracking of key sustainable development indicators and stores critical documents for quick access and future reference.

faqQ4: How Does a Government Implement Their Own NCTP?
faqA4:
Governments can adopt and customize the open-source National Climate Transparency Platform to meet their specific needs. By building on UNDP’s open-source codebase, countries can reduce development time and costs by up to 70%.

To implement the NCTP nationally, countries should have:
  • A Delivery Team with expertise in:
    • Technical development: Backend and frontend development, DevOps, system administration, and cybersecurity (can be one or multiple individuals)
    • Climate data and systems: Familiarity with national climate information systems such as MRV platforms, GHG inventories, BURs/BTRs, and sectoral data sources. Capacity building: Experience in MRV training and stakeholder engagement (can be one or multiple individuals)
  • Essential IT Infrastructure, including:
    • Server space (cloud-based, local, or blockchain-integrated)
    • SSL/TLS certificates for encrypted communication
    • A secure domain name (e.g., HTTPS with a trusted certificate authority)
    • Firewalls and intrusion detection systems
    • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
    • Data encryption (at rest and in transit)
    • Regular security audits and penetration testing
    • Backup and disaster recovery protocols
  • Governance and Oversight
    • Implementation Project Board (Steering Committee): A cross-ministerial group, including IT/technology stakeholders, to guide decisions and steer the process
    • Designated Project Owner: Responsible for coordination, accountability, and delivery
  • Sustainability Planning
    • Sustainability Planning
      • A long-term maintenance plan
      • A dedicated IT and operations budget
faqA5:
As an open-source platform, the NCTP is highly flexible. Common customization areas include:
  • User Roles: Define categories, permissions, and access levels
  • Institutions and Sectors: Tailor to national structures and priorities
  • Verification: Assign validators for each data point
  • Documentation: Upload supporting files for each action, programme, or project
  • Data Parameters: Add custom parameters aligned with national reporting
  • Key Performance Indicators: Define KPIs for climate and development outcomes
  • Reporting Formats: Add or adapt Common Tabular Formats
  • API Integration: Enable automated data exchange with national systems
  • Hosting and SecurityCustomize database, storage, and access configurations
faqQ6: What technical assistance can UNDP provide?
faqA6:
Through your local UNDP country office, the UNDP Digital for Planet team may offer support to governments in the following areas (subject to availability and agreement):
  • Resources & Templates: Access to standard workplans, workflows, and configuration tools to support deployment.
  • International Expertise: Guidance from global experts in product development, IT, carbon markets, and policy.
  • Community of Practice: Ongoing access to a global network for collaboration, troubleshooting, and shared learning.
faqA7:
The UNDP Digital for Planet team, through local UNDP country offices, can offer support in several areas (subject to discussion):
  • Resources and Templates: Access to template workplans, process flows, and other tools to assist in customising and configuring the DTS.
  • Training and International Expertise: Support from experts in product management, IT, enhanced transparency, and policy to provide guidance, ensure quality assurance, and facilitate knowledge transfer.
  • Community of Practice: Ongoing access to an international community of practice for support and collaboration of using climate change digital tools for enhanced transparency.
faqQ8: Is the source code free to use?
faqA8:
Yes. The NCTP is released under the GNU Affero General Public License (AGPL-3.0), which allows:
  • Free use and customization
  • Redistribution of modified version
  • Requirement to publish updates on GitHub
  • Prohibition of relicensing under more restrictive terms

Please note: Any modified code must be published publicly (after removing sensitive data) to remain compliant
